column1: Kansas City lies in the Midwestern United States

column7: and moderate precipitation

column9: far removed from a significant body of water
column10: there is significant potential for extremes of hot and cold swings in temperature throughout the year. Unless otherwise stated
column11: normal figures below are based on data from 1981 to 2010 at Downtown Airport. The warmest month of the year is July
column12: with a 24-hour average temperature of 81.0 °F (27.2 °C). The summer months are hot
column13: but can get very hot and moderately humid
column14: with moist air riding up from the Gulf of Mexico. High temperatures surpass 100 °F (38 °C) on 5.6 days of the year
column15: and 90 °F (32 °C) on 47 days. The coldest month of the year is January
column16: with an average temperature of 31.0 °F (−0.6 °C). Winters are cold
column17: with 22 days where the high is at or below the freezing mark and 2.5 nights with a low at or below 0 °F (−18 °C). The official record maximum temperature is 113 °F (45 °C)
column21: while the official record minimum temperature is −23 °F (−31 °C)
column23: 1989. Normal seasonal snowfall is 13.4 inches (34 cm) at Downtown Airport and 18.8 in (48 cm) at Kansas City International Airport. The average window for freezing temperatures is October 31 to April 4
column24: while for measurable (0.1 in or 0.25 cm) snowfall
column25: it is November 27 to March 16 as measured at Kansas City International Airport. Precipitation
column26: both in frequency and total accumulation

column1: Kansas City is situated on the edge of the "Tornado Alley"
column2: a broad region where cold air from the Rocky Mountains in Canada collides with warm air from the Gulf of Mexico
column3: leading to the formation of powerful storms especially during the spring. A few areas of the Kansas City Metropolitan Area have had some severe outbreaks of tornadoes at different points in the past
column4: including the Ruskin Heights tornado in 1957
column5: The Tornado Outbreak Sequence of May 2019 and the May 2003 tornado outbreak sequence. The region can also fall victim to the sporadic ice storm during the winter months
column6: such as the 2002 ice storm during which hundreds of thousands lost power for days and (in some cases) weeks. Kansas City and its outlying areas are also subject to flooding
column7: including the Great Flood of 1993 and the Great Flood of 1951.

column1: The Kansas City T-Bones is an independent baseball team in the American Association
column3: Kansas in 2003 and through 2019 played its home games at T-Bones Stadium
column4: located adjacent to the Village West development in western Wyandotte County. The team was previously a member of the Northern League (which was not affiliated with Major League Baseball)
column5: until it dissolved following the 2010 season. While the remaining Northern League teams became members of the North American League as part of the Northern League's merger with the Golden Baseball League and United Baseball League
column6: the T-Bones joined many other former Northern League teams in the relatively new American Association of Independent Professional Baseball. The T-Bones won the Northern League Championship in 2008 and the American Association Championship in 2018. The Unified Government evicted it from its stadium on October 14
column7: 2019 for nonpayment of rent and utilities.

column1: The Kansas Speedway is an auto racetrack adjacent to the Village West area in western Wyandotte County. The speedway
column2: which is used for races that are part of the NASCAR Sprint Cup and other racing series
column3: is a 1.5 miles (2.4 km) tri-oval with turns which bank at a 15° angle. The track held its first race on June 2
column5: when the Winston West series contested the Kansas 100. The top-level NASCAR Sprint Cup series holds the annual Hollywood Casino 400 at the track. The IZOD IndyCar Series previously had run the RoadRunner Turbo Indy 300 from 2001 to 2010; with IndyCar driver Scott Dixon setting the overall lap record for all series.
